preloaded/ententen21_tt31:
general context
----------------
- Corpus language: English.
- POS annotation tool: TreeTagger with Sketch Engine modifications (current pipeline version 3).
- Tagset is a modified TreeTagger tagset, itself related to the Penn Treebank tagset.
- Main structural differences from Penn:
  - All non-modal verbs are split into:
    - VB* = forms of “be”
    - VH* = forms of “have”
    - VV* = all other (non-modal) lexical verbs
  - Proper nouns:
    - Penn’s NNP → NP (proper noun, singular)
    - Penn’s NNPS → NPS (proper noun, plural)
  - SENT is used for sentence-final punctuation (. ! ?).
- Token “to”:
  - Tagged IN when used as a preposition.
  - Tagged TO only when used as an infinitive marker.
- Indefinite articles:
  - “a” and “an” are both lemmatized as “a”.
- Possessive clitics and numerals:
  - Possessive clitic (’s / ’) is re-tokenized and (almost always) joined to the preceding word.
  - Old tags POS, PP$, WP$ are replaced by:
    - Z (standalone possessive ending)
    - PPZ (possessive pronoun)
    - WPZ (possessive wh-pronoun)
  - New possessive tags: NNZ, NNSZ, NPZ, NPSZ, CDZ (possessive forms of nouns, proper nouns, numerals).
- Tokenization and other processing:
  - Updated models improve lemma guessing for possessives.
  - Tokenizer recognizes hashtags, user handles, emojis.
  - Improved sentence boundary detection around quotation marks.
  - Lemma for “would” is “would” (no stem reduction).


how CQL with tagset should be written
-------------------------------------
- POS tags are accessed in CQL via the attribute tag.
- Basic form: [tag="TAG"] where TAG is an exact tag string, e.g. [tag="NNS"].
- Tags must be written as:
  - exact, case-sensitive strings (all tags here are uppercase or punctuation characters),
  - with straight double quotes " " in CQL (no typographic quotes),
  - no extra spaces or modifiers inside the quotes.
  - This format is strict: [tag="NNS"] works, [tag="nns"] or [tag=" NNS "] does not.
- You can combine conditions with other attributes, e.g. [word="people" & tag="NNS"].
- Punctuation tags:
  - Many punctuation tags are the punctuation character itself (e.g. "," or "(") and must be quoted literally in CQL:
    - comma: [tag=","]
    - left bracket: [tag="("]
    - right bracket: [tag=")"]
    - currency symbol: [tag="$"]
    - hash: [tag="#"]
    - colon/dash/etc.: [tag=":"]
    - quote marks: [tag='"'] for double quote, [tag="'"] for single quote.
- Sentence-final punctuation uses tag SENT:
  - e.g. [tag="SENT"] for ., !, ? (do not search [tag="."] for sentence ends).
- Empty tag:
  - Tokens that are HTML or other entities in angle brackets have no POS tag.
  - In CQL, use [tag=""] to find such tokens.
- Special composite tag:
  - IN/that is a literal tag value for “that” as subordinator; use [tag="IN/that"].
- Tag values can be searched with regex on tag if supported, e.g. [tag="NN.*"] to find all noun tags, but literal values must still match exactly when not using regex metacharacters.


the tagset
----------
(Include both punctuation/other symbols and POS tags.)

(empty tag): HTML and other entities in angle brackets; token has no POS tag, use [tag=""].

" or ' (tag is the quote character itself): single or double quotation marks; [tag='"'] for " and [tag="'"] for '.

( : left brackets; tag is "(", covers ( [ {.

) : right brackets; tag is ")", covers ) ] }.

, : comma; tag is ",".

$ : currency symbols; tag is "$", covers $, £, €.

# : hash (number sign); tag is "#".

: : tag for various separators; covers dashes, ellipsis, underscore, (semi)colon: - … .. _ ; : .

SENT: sentence-break punctuation; covers . ! ?.

SYM: other symbols; covers / = * and similar symbols not listed above.

CC: coordinating conjunction; e.g. and; C = conjunction, doubled C for coordinating.

CD: cardinal number; numerals like 1, one; C = cardinal, D = digit/number.

CDZ: possessive numeral; e.g. one’s; CD = cardinal number, Z = possessive.

DT: determiner; e.g. the; D = determiner, T = type of determiner.

EX: existential there; e.g. there in “there is”; E = existential, X = expletive.

FW: foreign word; e.g. d’hoevre; F = foreign, W = word.

IN: preposition or subordinating conjunction; e.g. in, of, like; I = preposition/conjunction, N = general marker.

IN/that: “that” as a subordinator; literal tag string “IN/that”.

JJ: adjective; e.g. green; J = adjective.

JJR: comparative adjective; e.g. greener; JJ = adjective, R = comparative.

JJS: superlative adjective; e.g. greenest; JJ = adjective, S = superlative.

LS: list marker; e.g. 1); L = list, S = section.

MD: modal verb; e.g. could, will, should, would; M = modal, D = verb/auxiliary.

NN: common noun, singular or mass; e.g. table; NN = noun (base form).

NNS: common noun, plural; e.g. tables; NN = noun, S = plural.

NNSZ: possessive common noun, plural; e.g. people’s, women’s; NNS = plural noun, Z = possessive.

NNZ: possessive common noun, singular or mass; e.g. year’s, world’s; NN = noun, Z = possessive.

NP: proper noun, singular; e.g. John; N = noun, P = proper.

NPS: proper noun, plural; e.g. Vikings; NP = proper noun, S = plural.

NPSZ: possessive proper noun, plural; e.g. Boys’, Workers’; NPS = plural proper noun, Z = possessive.

NPZ: possessive proper noun, singular; e.g. Britain’s, God’s; NP = proper noun, Z = possessive.

PDT: predeterminer; e.g. both in “both the boys”; P = pre, DT = determiner.

PP: personal pronoun; e.g. I, he, it; P = pronoun, doubled P for personal.

PPZ: possessive pronoun; e.g. my, his; PP = personal pronoun, Z = possessive.

RB: adverb; e.g. however, usually, naturally, here, good (adverbial use); R = adverb, B = general adverb marker.

RBR: comparative adverb; e.g. better; RB = adverb, R = comparative.

RBS: superlative adverb; e.g. best; RB = adverb, S = superlative.

RP: particle; e.g. up in “give up”; R = particle class, P = particle.

SYM: symbols (except those with their own tags above); e.g. / = *; SYM = symbol.

TO: infinitive marker “to”; e.g. to go; T = “to”, O = marker; only when “to” marks infinitive (otherwise IN).

UH: interjection; e.g. uhhuhhuhh; U = interjection, H = exclamation.

VB: verb “be”, base form; e.g. be; V = verb, B = be.

VBD: verb “be”, past tense; e.g. was, were; VB = be-verb, D = past tense.

VBG: verb “be”, gerund/present participle; e.g. being; VB = be-verb, G = -ing form.

VBN: verb “be”, past participle; e.g. been; VB = be-verb, N = past participle.

VBP: verb “be”, present, non-3rd person; e.g. am, are; VB = be-verb, P = present (non-3sg).

VBZ: verb “be”, 3rd person singular present; e.g. is; VB = be-verb, Z = 3rd sg present.

VH: verb “have”, base form; e.g. have; V = verb, H = have.

VHD: verb “have”, past tense; e.g. had; VH = have-verb, D = past tense.

VHG: verb “have”, gerund/present participle; e.g. having; VH = have-verb, G = -ing form.

VHN: verb “have”, past participle; e.g. had; VH = have-verb, N = past participle.

VHP: verb “have”, singular present, non-3rd person; e.g. have; VH = have-verb, P = present (non-3sg).

VHZ: verb “have”, 3rd person singular present; e.g. has; VH = have-verb, Z = 3rd sg present.

VV: lexical (non-modal, non-be, non-have) verb, base form; e.g. take; V = verb, second V = lexical verb class.

VVD: lexical verb, past tense; e.g. took; VV = lexical verb, D = past tense.

VVG: lexical verb, gerund/present participle; e.g. taking; VV = lexical verb, G = -ing form.

VVN: lexical verb, past participle; e.g. taken; VV = lexical verb, N = past participle.

VVP: lexical verb, present, not 3rd person; e.g. take (I/you/we/they take); VV = lexical verb, P = present (non-3sg).

VVZ: lexical verb, 3rd person singular present; e.g. takes; VV = lexical verb, Z = 3rd sg present.

WDT: wh-determiner; e.g. which; W = wh-, DT = determiner.

WP: wh-pronoun; e.g. who, what; W = wh-, P = pronoun.

WPZ: possessive wh-pronoun; e.g. whose; WP = wh-pronoun, Z = possessive.

WRB: wh-adverb; e.g. where, when; W = wh-, RB = adverb.

Z: possessive ending; standalone clitic ’s; e.g. [tag="Z"] for tokens that are just ’s.
preloaded/frtenten22_fl4:
general context
- Corpus language: French.
- Tagger: FreeLing morphological tagger for French, based on EAGLES-style positional tags.
- Tagset type: mainly positional (each character encodes one feature at a fixed position), plus a small set of non-positional tags for punctuation.
- Use in Sketch Engine: tags are accessible via the `tag` attribute in CQL.

how CQL with tagset should be written
- Tags are single, case-sensitive strings with fixed positions (no separators); each character position has a specific meaning depending on the POS.
- Tag format is strict: each position must contain exactly one of the allowed values for that POS. To search flexibly, use regular-expression wildcards in CQL rather than changing the order/number of characters.
- In CQL, use the `tag` attribute, e.g.:
  - `[tag="N.FS.*"]` matches feminine singular nouns: `N` at position 0 (noun), any value at position 1, `F` at position 2 (feminine), `S` at position 3 (singular), anything in remaining positions.
  - `[tag="V..I.*"]` matches verbs in the imperfect tense: `V` at position 0 (verb), any value at positions 1–2, `I` at position 3 (imperfect tense), anything in remaining positions.
- Wildcards in CQL:
  - `.` = any single character at that position.
  - `.*` = any sequence (including empty) of characters from that position to the end of the tag.
- Always use straight double quotes around tags in CQL: `[tag="..."]`, not curly quotes.
- Punctuation tags are non-positional fixed strings like `Fd`, `Fc`, `Fp` etc.; match them literally in CQL, e.g. `[tag="Fp"]`.

the tagset

POS: adjective (category A, positional)
- Position 0: category – `A` = adjective.
- Position 1: type – `O` = ordinal; `Q` = qualificative; `P` = possessive.
- Position 2: degree – `S` = superlative; `V` = evaluative.
- Position 3: gender – `F` = feminine; `M` = masculine; `C` = common gender; `N` = neuter.
- Position 4: number – `S` = singular; `P` = plural; `N` = invariable.
- Position 5: possessor person – `1` = 1st person; `2` = 2nd person; `3` = 3rd person.
- Position 6: possessor number – `S` = singular; `P` = plural; `N` = invariable.

POS: conjunction (category C, positional)
- Position 0: category – `C` = conjunction.
- Position 1: type – `C` = coordinating conjunction; `S` = subordinating conjunction.

POS: determiner (category D, positional)
- Position 0: category – `D` = determiner.
- Position 1: type – `A` = article; `D` = demonstrative; `E` = exclamative; `I` = indefinite; `T` = interrogative; `N` = numeral; `P` = possessive; `R` = relative.
- Position 2: person – `1` = 1st person; `2` = 2nd person; `3` = 3rd person.
- Position 3: gender – `F` = feminine; `M` = masculine; `C` = common gender; `N` = neuter.
- Position 4: number – `S` = singular; `P` = plural; `N` = invariable.
- Position 5: possessor number – `S` = singular; `P` = plural.

POS: noun (category N, positional)
- Position 0: category – `N` = noun.
- Position 1: type – `C` = common noun; `P` = proper noun.
- Position 2: gender – `F` = feminine; `M` = masculine; `C` = common gender; `N` = neuter.
- Position 3: number – `S` = singular; `P` = plural; `N` = invariable.
- Position 4: named-entity class – `S` = person; `G` = location; `O` = organization; `V` = other.
- Position 5: named-entity subclass – not used.
- Position 6: degree – `A` = augmentative; `D` = diminutive.

POS: pronoun (category P, positional)
- Position 0: category – `P` = pronoun.
- Position 1: type – `D` = demonstrative; `E` = exclamative; `I` = indefinite; `T` = interrogative; `N` = numeral; `P` = personal; `X` = possessive; `R` = relative.
- Position 2: person – `1` = 1st person; `2` = 2nd person; `3` = 3rd person.
- Position 3: gender – `F` = feminine; `M` = masculine; `C` = common gender; `N` = neuter.
- Position 4: number – `S` = singular; `P` = plural; `N` = invariable.
- Position 5: case – `N` = nominative; `A` = accusative; `D` = dative; `O` = oblique.
- Position 6: politeness – `P` = polite form (yes).

POS: adverb (category R, positional)
- Position 0: category – `R` = adverb.
- Position 1: type – `N` = negative adverb; `G` = general adverb.

POS: adposition (preposition) (category S, positional)
- Position 0: category – `S` = adposition.
- Position 1: type – `P` = preposition.

POS: verb (category V, positional)
- Position 0: category – `V` = verb.
- Position 1: type – `M` = main verb; `A` = auxiliary; `S` = semi-auxiliary.
- Position 2: mood – `I` = indicative; `S` = subjunctive; `M` = imperative; `P` = participle; `G` = gerund; `N` = infinitive.
- Position 3: tense – `P` = present; `I` = imperfect; `F` = future; `S` = past; `C` = conditional.
- Position 4: person – `1` = 1st person; `2` = 2nd person; `3` = 3rd person.
- Position 5: number – `S` = singular; `P` = plural.
- Position 6: gender – `F` = feminine; `M` = masculine; `C` = common gender; `N` = neuter.

POS: number (category Z, positional)
- Position 0: category – `Z` = number.
- Position 1: type – `d` = partitive number; `m` = currency; `p` = percentage; `u` = unit.

POS: date (category W, positional)
- Position 0: category – `W` = date.

POS: interjection (category I, positional)
- Position 0: category – `I` = interjection.

Non-positional tags: punctuation (fixed strings)
- `Fd` – punctuation; type: colon.
- `Fc` – punctuation; type: comma.
- `Flt` – punctuation; type: curly bracket; `punctenclose`: close.
- `Fla` – punctuation; type: curly bracket; `punctenclose`: open.
- `Fs` – punctuation; type: etc. (ellipsis/other etc.-like punctuation).
- `Fat` – punctuation; type: exclamation mark; `punctenclose`: close.
- `Faa` – punctuation; type: exclamation mark; `punctenclose`: open.
- `Fg` – punctuation; type: hyphen.
- `Fz` – punctuation; type: other punctuation.
- `Fpt` – punctuation; type: parenthesis; `punctenclose`: close.
- `Fpa` – punctuation; type: parenthesis; `punctenclose`: open.
- `Ft` – punctuation; type: percentage sign.
- `Fp` – punctuation; type: period (full stop).
- `Fit` – punctuation; type: question mark; `punctenclose`: close.
- `Fia` – punctuation; type: question mark; `punctenclose`: open.
- `Fe` – punctuation; type: quotation mark (generic).
- `Frc` – punctuation; type: quotation mark; `punctenclose`: close.
- `Fra` – punctuation; type: quotation mark; `punctenclose`: open.
- `Fx` – punctuation; type: semicolon.
- `Fh` – punctuation; type: slash.
- `Fct` – punctuation; type: square bracket; `punctenclose`: close.
- `Fca` – punctuation; type: square bracket; `punctenclose`: open.

Reminder on strict format
- For positional tags, each character position (0,1,2,3,4,5,6, … as applicable) must use exactly one of the specified values; you cannot change order or insert/delete positions.
- In CQL, rely on regular-expression wildcards (`.` and `.*`) to ignore or generalize over positions while respecting the strict, fixed tag format.
